awd_titl_txt: Probing Super-Critical Electromagnetic Fields with Petawatt Lasers
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports efforts to design experiments for the new National Science Foundation-funded high intensity Zettawatt-Equivalent Ultrashort pulse laser System (ZEUS) facility.  High peak-power lasers, such as the ZEUS multi-Petawatt laser can generate extreme electromagnetic fields through focusing the power down to a tiny spot. These fields are capable of accelerating charged particles to near the speed of light in a fraction of a million billionth of a second, producing bright, point-like sources of radiation. In such strong fields, high-energy gamma-rays can spontaneously decay into pairs of matter-antimatter particles, leading to matter creation from light. This project will design experiments for the ZEUS facility to measure matter creation and amplification of the process through a chain reaction.  The project will support graduate students and should enable a study of dense and ultrashort duration beams of antimatter.

The ZEUS laser facility will generate few-gigaelectronvolt electron beams through laser wakefield acceleration, which is a method for generating beams of electrons using the accelerating field structure produced in a plasma in the wake of a high-power, ultrashort pulsed laser. By colliding the electron beam with a second, tightly focused, high-power laser pulse, the field strength is expected to greatly exceed the critical field of quantum electrodynamics in the electron rest frame, leading to electron-positron pair production. Graduate students will participate in designing and building particle detectors for ZEUS experiments, the plasma target for controlled injection of stable monoenergetic beams and guiding of the laser to achieve multi-GeV energies, and modelling the laser-electron collision physics using advanced quantum kinetic codes. Understanding the laser interaction physics is crucial for the frontier ZEUS experiments to be successful. In the final year of the project, laser time with ZEUS is anticipated to be available for the first runs for this frontier experiment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The states of matter generated in super-critically strong electromagnetic fields are found in extreme astrophysical objects such as neutron stars and the exteriors of black holes. These states will be produced in the laboratory using new lasers exceeding a quadrillion watts in power. The interactions of particles with such strong fields are poorly understood due to theoretical difficulties. Well-designed experiments with suitable diagnostics are crucial to addressing these challenges. In this project, we developed new theoretical tools and experimental diagnostics to understand the physics of frontier strong-field quantum electrodynamics experiments to be conducted at these new ultra-high intensity laser facilities, including the National Science Foundation-funded ZEUS laser.
Understanding the behavior of plasma in extreme fields is a fundamentally interesting problem that relates to our understanding of extreme astrophysical objects such as magnetars and black hole exteriors. It is also crucial to comprehend plasma physics in these extreme fields to support the significant investments in ultrahigh-power laser facilities in the U.S. and around the world, including NSF investments in ZEUS and EP-OPAL. This understanding is necessary for developing high-intensity lasers and their myriad applications, such as new radiation sources for medical, defense, national security, and industrial purposes. Additionally, training skilled graduate students in high power lasers is important. For example, a graduate student trained on this project now works in the semiconductor manufacturing industry.
We have developed a comprehensive spin and polarization-inclusive QED module based on the particle-in-cell code OSIRIS. In this module, lepton spin dynamics involves both the classical spin precession process described by the T-BMT equation and the quantum radiation reaction-induced spin transition process. The photon polarization-resolved quantum radiation rate allows us to assign a polarization state to each generated photon in the simulation. We also consider the influence of lepton spin and photon polarization on the non-linear Breit-Wheeler pair production process. Compared to state-of-the-art, typically spin/polarization-averaged QED modules, this fully spin/polarization-distinguished quantum module is able to more accurately simulate multi-stage processes, including avalanche and shower-type electron-positron pair-production cascades.
For measuring energetic photons, a gamma-ray spectrometer has been built that can accurately measure spectra during a single shot and at high repetition rates to match the ZEUS laser's capabilities. The design is related to a filter stack spectrometer (FSS) that relies on energy attenuation as photons propagate through an alternating series of filter materials and detectors like image plates or scintillating crystals. This attenuation produces a pattern of intensity values corresponding to the incident spectrum, allowing an algorithm to unfold this spectrum from the signal.
Additionally, the project has contributed to several other scientific results, including spatiotemporal control of light pulses to produce intensity peaks that move independently of the expected light speed. This controlled motion of the intensity peak suggests a new approach to optimizing laser-based applications and enhancing signatures of fundamental phenomena. A concept for a femtosecond pulse compressor using underdense plasma prisms was developed to overcome the damage threshold of conventional gratings used in the chirped pulse amplification necessary for generating the highest power lasers. We have also contributed to several other advancements in positron and gamma ray sources.
